summary: This is a formal letter from the French Ministry of Justice's International Criminal Assistance Bureau to the U.S. Department of Justice, dated March 9, 2021. It explains French law regarding extradition, specifically stating that French nationality at the time of an alleged offense is an absolute bar to extradition from France, and that subsequent loss of nationality does not change this.

persons.name: Monsieur le garde des Sceaux, ministre de la Justice
persons.role: Minister of Justice (Keeper of the Seals)
persons.context: The French Minister of Justice is the formal addressee of the letter, which is being forwarded to the U.S. Department of Justice.

persons.name: Liaison Magistrate
persons.role: Liaison Magistrate at the U.S. Embassy
persons.context: The letter is being transmitted to the U.S. Department of Justice through this official at the U.S. Embassy in Paris.

persons.name: Head of the International Criminal Assistance Bureau
persons.context: The official who signed and sent this legal clarification from the French Ministry of Justice.

locations: Embassy of the United States of America, Paris, France
keyFacts: French law (Articles 696 et seq. of the Code of Criminal Procedure) governs extradition.
Article 694-4 expressly prohibits extradition if the individual had French citizenship at the time the alleged offense was committed.
This French nationality barrier is described as an 'insuperable obstacle' to extradition.
Loss of French nationality after the alleged offense has no bearing on the extradition assessment; the key date is the time of the offense.
The document is a formal response to a U.S. request, clarifying a significant legal hurdle in international cooperation for this case.
